Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
Evidence Statements: The student can draw and label the material before heating or cooling (e.g., a whole egg and ice cube).
The student can draw and label the material after heating (e.g., a cooked egg, melted ice as water).
The student can draw and label the material after cooling (e.g., water as ice again).
The student can illustrate the reversible change by showing water turning back into ice and vice versa.
The student can illustrate the irreversible change by showing a cooked egg that cannot turn back into a raw egg.
The student can use arrows or other visual markers to indicate whether changes are reversible or irreversible.
The student can provide a caption or description explaining whether each change (e.g., melting, cooking) can be reversed and why.
